1. Hamlet: Perhaps the most famous of Shakespeare's characters, Hamlet is a complex and conflicted figure, haunted by the ghost of his father and driven to revenge against his uncle. In performances of the play, actors have brought a range of personality traits to the role, from brooding introspection to explosive rage. One particularly famous portrayal of Hamlet is Laurence Olivier's 1948 film version, in which he conveys the character's indecision and inner turmoil.

2. Lady Macbeth: Shakespeare's Lady Macbeth is a powerful and ambitious figure, driven by her desire for power and status. On stage, actresses have often emphasized her ruthless and manipulative nature, as well as her psychological instability. In the 2015 film version of Macbeth, Marion Cotillard brings a haunted quality to the role, conveying the character's guilt and descent into madness.

3. Othello: Shakespeare's Othello is a tragic figure, brought down by jealousy and the machinations of others. In performances of the play, actors have brought a range of personality traits to the role, from confidence and determination to insecurity and self-doubt. One particularly memorable portrayal is Laurence Fishburne's 1995 film version, in which he conveys the character's nobility and passion, as well as his vulnerability.

4. Romeo and Juliet: Shakespeare's star-crossed lovers are among his most iconic characters, and their personalities are brought to life on stage through their dialogue and actions. Romeo is often portrayed as passionate and impulsive, while Juliet is sensitive and introspective. In the 1968 film version, Leonard Whiting and Olivia Hussey bring youthful energy and vulnerability to the roles, capturing the intensity of the characters' emotions.

5. Falstaff: Shakespeare's Falstaff is a larger-than-life character, known for his bawdy humor and love of drink. On stage, actors have portrayed him as a lovable rogue, a witty and irreverent companion, or a more cynical figure who uses his charm to manipulate others. One particularly famous portrayal is Orson Welles' 1965 film adaptation of the Henry IV plays, in which he brings a larger-than-life energy to the character, conveying his wit, humor, and ultimately his tragedy.
